You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 602]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 904, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 784, 184, 800]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 784, 568, 800]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Pour \(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 801, 659, 817]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Place the thermometer in the hot water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 818, 661, 834]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 835, 917, 863]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Without delay, use the measuring cylinder to add \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of the cold water to the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 864, 449, 880]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Stir the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 881, 830, 897]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Record in Table 2.1 the temperature of the mixture of hot and cold water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 897, 917, 925]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Repeat the procedure, adding \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of cold water each time, until you have a total of \(200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 926, 916, 942]]<|/det|>
[3]

Draw a line 10.0 cm long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line MR. Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal NL. Label the point at which NL crosses MR with the letter B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 646, 184, 662]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 679, 707, 695]]<|/det|>
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line MR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 696, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\), on line AB at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\).

Label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[147, 570, 852, 602]]<|/det|>
<pre>Write your name, centre number and candidate number on your ray-trace sheet. Tie your ray-trace sheet into this question booklet between pages 8 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 103, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 846, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter and the resistance of wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 104, 420, 120]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 135, 400, 151]]<|/det|>
· wires with different diameters

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 153, 548, 168]]<|/det|>
· instrument for measuring the diameter of a wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 170, 240, 182]]<|/det|>
· metre ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 186, 240, 198]]<|/det|>
· ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 201, 240, 213]]<|/det|>
· voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 216, 273, 229]]<|/det|>
· power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 244, 704, 260]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 274, 796, 290]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects its resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 300, 918, 336]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R=\frac{V}{I}\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 352, 903, 368]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation. You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 383, 224, 399]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 414, 175, 430]]<|/det|>
· draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit you use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 432, 490, 446]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 448, 485, 462]]<|/det|>
· state **one** key variable to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 464, 918, 496]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 498, 600, 511]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 32, 415, 70]]<|/det|>
